did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the ADF Archives.
did.abstract: Dance Pages (circa 1983-1997), a quarterly magazine, presented its readers with articles about a wide range of dance genres, performances, companies, and individual dancers. The magazine also contained studio listings, book and video reviews, and information about dance history and health. Kenneth Romo and Donna Gianell, both professional dancers, created Dance Pages as a hobby, and they continued to serve as the publishers and editors of the magazine as it grew in size and scope. In 1995, the magazine changed names, becoming Dance & the Arts, and moved to a bimonthly publication schedule. The magazine dissolved around 1997. The collection includes publicity information, magazines, drafts of articles and advertisements, paste-ups for advertisements and magazine features, newspaper clippings, press kits, programs, flyers, brochures, catalogs, invoices, personal and professional correspondence, photographs, contact sheets, negatives, 35 mm slides, and transparencies.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
In off-site storage; 48 hours advance notice is required for use.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for official American Dance Festival administrative records is held by the American Dance Festival; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Dance Pages Records, American Dance Festival Archives.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Dance Pages Records were received by the American Dance Festival Archives as a gift in 2013.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Dance Pages (circa 1983-1997), a quarterly magazine, presented its readers with articles about a wide range of dance genres, performances, companies, and individual dancers. The magazine also contained studio listings, book and video reviews, and information about dance history and health. Kenneth Romo and Donna Gianell, both professional dancers, created Dance Pages as a hobby, and they continued to serve as the publishers and editors of the magazine as it grew in size and scope. In 1995, the magazine changed names, becoming Dance & the Arts, and moved to a bimonthly publication schedule. The magazine dissolved around 1997.

The husband and wife team of Romo and Gianell originally conceived the magazine as a way to provide local and visiting dance students with comprehensive information about New York City teachers, dance studios, and schedules. In the mid-1980s, Dance Pages was incorporated and began to expand into the national market in both advertising and editorial coverage. Designed to appeal to a broad audience, the magazine published articles about a wide range of dance, including classical ballet, modern, tap, jazz, ballroom, and ethnic dance, as well as dance history. It also covered a variety of performance platforms for dance, such as concert, video, television, film, Broadway, and festivals. In addition, Dance Pages featured information about health, dance injury-related exercises, and conditioning and toning exercises. Book, video, and Broadway reviews also appeared in the magazine. Dance Pages, and later Dance & the Arts, continued to feature listings of both New York City and national studios.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the records of Dance Pages, which were collected or created during the production of the magazine, as well as copies of the magazine from 1987 to 1997. Records were typically filed by subject or person rather than by type of record, so files contain a range of materials. The majority of the Dance Pages records are subject files, which primarily contain publicity information such as photographs and press releases for dance companies, dancers, schools, teachers, artists, musicians, filmmakers, photographers, performance venues, events, performances, and other dance-related topics. In addition to publicity materials, subject folders can contain drafts of articles and advertisements, paste-ups for advertisements and magazine features, illustrated graphics, press clippings, correspondence, invoices, brochures, flyers, programs, 35 mm slides, and negatives. The collection also contains administrative files, which hold materials related to magazine contributors, personnel, and business management. While the collection includes some financial documentation and correspondence, these materials are filed with the subject to which they pertain and are therefore distributed throughout the collection.

The materials housed within the collection are in a variety of formats, including paper-based records, magazines, paste-ups, illustrated graphics, newspaper clippings, press kits, programs, flyers, brochures, and catalogs, as well as photographs, contact sheets, negatives, 35 mm slides, and transparencies.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into three series: Magazines, Subject Files, and Administrative Files.

scopecontent.p: The Magazines series contains copies of Dance Pages magazine, beginning with Spring 1987 (vol. 5, no. 1) and ending with September/October 1997 (vol. 15, no. 2). Two issues from 1987 (vol. 5, no. 2-3) and issues published before 1987 are not included in the collection.

arrangement.p: The Subject Files series is divided into seven subseries.

scopecontent.p: The Dance and Arts Associations subseries contains press releases, newsletters, reports, brochures, programs, correspondence, and a press information packet.

did.unittitle: Dance/USA Annual Report and Three Year Plan, 1985
New York Foundation for the Arts National Dance Residency Program Grants, 1994

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically. One folder containing unidentified photographs is filed under "unidentified."

scopecontent.p: The majority of the materials in the Dance Companies and Dancers subseries are publicity photographs and press releases. Other materials include drafts of articles, advertisement copy, paste-ups, press clippings, resumes, correspondence, invoices, brochures, flyers, programs, contact sheets, 35 mm slides, and negatives. All folders in the subseries contain photographs, with the exception of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre, Gary Duncan, ISO, Belinda James, Sankai Juku, Diane Latchrupp and Paul Pellicorno, Sun Ock Lee, Neryda, and Newark Dance Theatre.

scopecontent.p: The Dance-Related Topics subseries contains information pertaining to massage and physical therapy, hair and makeup, careers outside of professional dance, reviews of videos, television specials, and books, and other dance-related subjects. Materials include photographs, contact sheets, article drafts, correspondence, press releases, press clippings, and a coloring book.

scopecontent.p: The Events, Performances, and Venues subseries contains information pertaining to festivals, dance pieces, performances, dance competitions, theaters, and other arts venues. Materials include photographs, contact sheets, 35 mm slides, negatives, illustrated graphics, press clippings, press releases, press kits, brochures, article drafts, handwritten notes, and correspondence. Subjects of photographs are listed in the folder description when they differ from the folder title.
Contains photograph from Joseph Cashore's Lullaby and Other Stories.

scopecontent.p: The Photographers subseries contains photographs, contact sheets, a transparency, article drafts, paste-ups, brochures, flyers, invoices, handwritten notes, and correspondence. Subjects of photographs are listed in the folder description when they differ from the folder title.

Contains photographs of The Bronx Dance Theatre, Quentin Clark, Eiko & Koma, Eleo Pomare Dance Company, Charles Grant, Kenneth Hillard, Randy Howard, Saeko Ichinohe, Claire Iwatsu, Stanley Joseph, John Juhl, Charles Malik Lewis, Peggy Lyman, Patricia Page, Eleo Pomare, Thomas Reid, Evelyn Shepard, Peter Sparling, Ray Tadio, Osamu Uehara, George White Jr., and Leni Wylliams.

The Schools and Teachers subseries contains photographs, negatives, and press releases. Subjects of photographs are listed in the folder description when they differ from the folder title.

did.unittitle: Visual Artists, Filmmakers, and Musicians, 1986-1995, undated

scopecontent.p: The Visual Artists, Filmmakers, and Musicians subseries contains photographs of both artists and works of art, hand drawn cartoons, negatives, advertisement and article paste-ups, press clippings, brochures, flyers, programs, correspondence, resumes, biographical notes, and a magazine.

did.unittitle: Rusty Frank - Tap! The Tempo of America, 1992

scopecontent.p: Contains information about Laurel Stern, Jimac, Ross Lewis, and Robert Lederman.

The Administrative Files series holds records pertaining to a range of subjects. Some files contain materials related to magazine contributors, writers, and personnel, such as article drafts, poetry, timesheets, invoices, resumes, writing samples, and correspondence. Other files contain materials pertaining to business management, such as customer directories, invoices, professional correspondence, advertising leads, advertising solicitation letters, budgets, a two-year plan, and a history of Dance Pages. Additional materials include supply catalogs, brochures, photocopy request forms and receipts, magazine reply card layouts, personal correspondence, handwritten notes, press clippings, performance programs, a cooperative society newsletter, a magazine, photographs, and 35 mm slides.
